definition: Structured, bilateral handling of amendments, waivers, and scope adjustments with recorded rationale.

positive_examples: Change requests cite the clauses affected and telemetry evidence.
Both parties sign off on change logs with timestamps.
Scope adjustments include updated verification plans.
Waivers expire automatically unless renewed jointly.
Change board agendas circulate in advance with full packets.
Observers confirm probe impacts before approval.
Rejections include documented reasoning and next steps.
Digital change tools enforce required metadata fields.
Historic changes remain searchable by clause.
Budget shifts link back to change decisions.
Counterparties share impact assessments before votes.
Change backlog shows prioritization agreed by both sides.
Templates capture risks introduced by each change.
Change cadence is predictable and published.
negative_examples: Scope creep enters without documented approval.
One party edits the contract unilaterally.
Waivers never expire so obligations vanish.
Change boards meet irregularly with no notice.
Telemetry references are missing from change requests.
Observers are excluded from amendment meetings.
Reasons for rejection are 'because leadership said so'.
Emergency changes never get reviewed afterwards.
Budget shifts occur without linking to clauses.
Change backlog is private to one party.
Change history is stored on personal drives.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured, bilateral handling of amendments, waivers, and scope adjustments with recorded rationale.
